former_owner_as_recorded: Carlo Archinto of Milan (1669-1732); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco. A letter from George Moss (librarian of Sutro) addressed to Mrs. Morbio (presumably Mrs. Albert Morbio, Sutro's daughter), 23 May 1890, accompanies the manuscript.
physical_description: Binding: Green vellum.|Figurative details, ff. 1r-48v: One inhabited initial on gold ground; bust of a bishop on a red shield carrying the name Alexander inside a green wreath.|Other decoration, ff. 1r-48v: Border along lower edge of f. 1 of sprays of flowers decorated with gold balls; 2- and 3-line initials alternating in blue and gold with pen flourishing in red and blue respectively; headings in red centered above blocks of text.|Number of scribes, ff. 1r-48v: 1.|Script, ff. 1r-48v: Humanistic.|Layout, ff. 1r-48v: 25 long lines ruled in ink.
note: Manuscript note: In house call number: Sutro PA 4267 P3 1464.|Bibliography: Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1r-48v: Scribal colophon, 4. 46r; back pastedown from another manuscript; written surface faces board, making writing only faintly visible.|ff. 1r-46r: ff. 44v-45v, 4 additional letters with preface to Alfonso of Naples; f. 46, letter to Francesco Pellotus of Padua; ownership note. f. 46r; ff. 46v-47v blank; 2 alphabets & excerpts from Sallust and Lucan, signed "A. B" on f. 48r; f. 48v blank.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

former_owner_as_recorded: The dean of Lu"kirch; Carthusians of Buxheim (cf. note on f. i verso), with "N. 175" in ink on f. 1 and on the spine; "386" also on the spine; Hugo, Graf von Waldbott-Basenheim (Munich, 20 Sept. 1883, lot 2616); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of S. F.
former_owner_label: Dean of Lukirch;Buxheim Charterhouse;Hugo Philipp Waldbott-Bassenheim;Adolph Sutro
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XV, in red leather over boards bevelled on the outside, two fore edge clasps with straps closing to pins; design of a church on the clasps. Unidentified fragments of another manuscript as pastedowns and flyleaves.|Script, ff. 1-107v: Semi-cursive gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-107v: 29-34 long lines, frame ruled in lead.|Script, Pastedowns, flyleaves: Cursive gothic.|Layout, Pastedowns, flyleaves: 2 columns.
note: Bibliography: J. B. Schneyer, Repertorium der lateinischen Sermones des Mittelalters fu"r die Zeit von 1350 bis 1500(Mu"nster 1969-1990).|ff. 1-107v: As in J. B. Schneyer, Repertorium sermons: 2, 5, 6, 9, 17, 18, 21-26, ?, 28-45, 47-106, 108-110, 112-131, 133, 134, 136-141, 143-150, ?, ?, 152, 154, 156-159, 161-163, 165, 167, 169-172, 175, 178-182, 184, 193, 186-192, ?, ?.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

title_as_recorded: Re'gime du corps|M ccc lxxxxii. Qui chomincia la fisicha del maestro Aldobrandino da Siena il quale chonpuose in linghua franciescha della santa del chorpo del uomo e di ciaschuno nenbro per se traslatata in volghare per ser Zucchero Bencivenni notaio fiorentino . . .
scribe_as_recorded: Jachopo di Domenicho vinattiere de' Seghalorzi di Firenze
associated_agent_as_recorded: Zucchero Bencivenni, translator from French to Italian
former_owner_as_recorded: Inside front cover: Ex bibliotheca Com. Eq. Fabricii Orsini Rilli di Poppi. N. 263 in a Sotheby sale, ca. 1890 (according to De Ricci); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XV, in half calf over squared wooden boards, wrapped with two purple ribbons, 5 brass bosses on spine with evidence of 5 others; clasp missing.|Number of scribes, ff. 1-69v: 2 breaking between ff. 17v-18.|Script, ff. 1-69v: Mercantesca; cancelleresca.|Layout, ff. 1-69v: Gatherings of 12 leaves; 30-39 long lines frame ruled in lead.|Watermarks, ff. 1-69v: Briquet 10489 and another similar to Briquet 11659-1168.
note: Manuscript note: Burnt on fore edge, possibly from the 1906 fire in San Francisco that destroyed most of the Sutro Collection.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 26 as n. 2.|ff. 1-69v: Date and scribe's name on f. 1, in the opening rubric: "M ccc lxxxxii . . . lo scrisse Jachopo di Domenicho vinattiere de Seghalorzi di Firenze." Parchment reinforcing strips around the back of each quire.|Explicit, ff. 1-68v; f. 69r-v blank: Domene dio per sua grande possanza tutto il mondo istabilito.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

former_owner_as_recorded: On f. 121, rubric for St. John the Baptist "patroni ordinis nostri et ecclesie huius"; Carthusians of Buxheim; in the sale of Hugo, Graf von Waldbott-Bassenheim (Munich, 20 September 1883, lot 2533); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVI, in stamped white vellum over wooden boards bevelled to the inside; evidence of 2 fore edge clasps; fore edge leather tabs at major text divisions.|Script, ff. 1-143: Liturgical gothic book hand.|Music, ff. 1-143: Musical notation.|Layout, ff. 1-143: 9 sets of text and 4-line red staves to the page; quires mainly of 8 leaves.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 26 as n. 3.|ff. 1-143: Contemporary pagination in red roman numerals.|ff. 1-142v; f. 143r-v blank: On ff. 1-110, temporale from Advent to 23rd Sunday after Pentecost; ff. 110-140, sanctorale adds: Francis de Paula, Catherine of Siena, Anthony of Padua, Bonaventure, Agatha, Afra, Bernard, Nicolas of Tolentino, Francis, Bruno, Gallus.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

former_owner_as_recorded: Ownership notes, mainly illegible, inside front cover, ". . . Ambroggio 1523 ad oct. A<?> ... Salus..." and " 692." De Ricci states that the volume was "last in Germany." Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVI, in the original pasteboard wrapper in notarial style with later note on the front cover "Scriptum ca. seculo XII."|Script, ff. 1-140v: Cursive gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-140v: Gatherings 1, 8-10 of 14 leaves, all others of 12; reinforcing strip from notarial document in gutter of innermost bifolium; quires signed with letter of alphabet on last verso, repeated catchword-like on facing recto. Frame ruled in lead.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 26 n. 4.|ff. 1-140v: ff. 1-11, index; ff. 11v-12 non-indexed recipes in a different hand; ff. 12v-13 blank; ff. 14-16, non-indexed recipes, some in Latin; f. 16v, table of weight measurements; ff. 17-140v main text.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

former_owner_as_recorded: Rosenthal, antiquarian bookdealer in Munich; Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
physical_description: Binding: Bound in a booklet bearing the note that the leaves were acquired by Mr. Sutro from Rosenthal, Munich.|Script, ff. 1-3v: Liturgical gothic book hand.|Layout, ff. 1-3v: 15 long lines ruled in pale red ink.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 26 as n. 6.|ff. 1-3v: Openings of the Hours of the Virgin, the Office of Holy Spirit, and the Office of the Dead.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

former_owner_as_recorded: Carthusians of Buxheim; Hugo, Graf von Waldbott-Bassenhim (his sale, Munich, 20 September 1883, lot 2672); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
physical_description: Binding: Bound in stamped leather overs wooden boards with 2 fore edge brass clasps; some gilt tooling.; 15 fore edge tabs to mark major text divisions.|Script, ff. 1-78v: Liturgical gothic book hand.|Music, ff. 1-78v: On 4-line red staves.|Layout, ff. 1-78v: Gatherings of 8, catchwords present, quire and leaf signatures in letter of the alphabet and roman numeral (out of order in 7th quire); 18 long lines of text.
note: Bibliography: Possibly to be identified with the manuscript described by De Ricci on p. 26 at n. 1 (but wrong text ?, wrong number of leaves, and wrong lot number in Waldbott-Bassenheim sale, which De Ricci says was 2640).|ff. 1-78v: On ff. 1-46v, psalter; ff. 46v-58, hymns; ff. 58-78v, office for the dead.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

title_as_recorded: De corpore et sanguine Domini|De die iudicii|Incipit epistola Petri Damiani de die iudicii|Materials relating to Cesena
standard_title: De corpore et sanguine Domini|De die iudicii|De die iudicii|
former_owner_as_recorded: On f. 1, illegilbe even under ultra-violet light due to stain, "Iste liber est monachorum <?> deputatus monasterii <sancte Marie ?> <?>." On f. i verso in a modern Italian hand, "14.6.13" written over "A.42000." Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of S. F.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XIX with labels on spine, "Paschasii De corpore et sanguine Domini" and "Bertoni opera."|Number of scribes, ff. 1-38v: 1.
note: Bibliography: Not in De Ricci.|ff. 39-135: Terminus post quem provided by texts: f. 132, death note of Bonaventura Bertoni in 1719; ff. 133-134, speech by Pope Innocent in 1666 and a rhyme in Italian of an event in 1686.|ff. 1-36: On f. 1, Regis adire sacre qui vis sollemnia mense . . . (15 verses spelling "Radbertus levita"); ff. 1-2, dedicatory letter.|Explicit, ff. 1-36: Quisquis catholicorum recte dominum cuncta creasse de nichilo.|Explicit, ff. 36-38v: Dilectissimo fratri Ade Petrus peccator monachus humilis in domino salutem. Quod me, frater karissime, quid ante mundi creationem fuerit . . .|ff. 39-135: ff. 39-45v, life of St. Maurus by Maurus Verdoni; ff. 47-111v, sermons in Italian; f. 112v, list of schismatic Greeks; ff. 113-114v, Memorialein first person, signed J. Bonaventura Cesenas Capuccinus; ff. 115-132, Elucidationesagainst Calvinists.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

title_as_recorded: Book of Hours, use of Rome
associated_agent_as_recorded: Paolo Signarri, S. J. (author of added prayers in Italian? cf. f. 21v)
former_owner_as_recorded: On ff. 105v, 109v-141v, in margins, notes of the Floriani family, 1591-1702, in areas near Bologna (S. Martino in Argile, S. Lorenzo del Castello di Budrio, Dozza; Budrio); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVII, in leather over pasteboards, blind stamped with a rosette surrounding the IHS monogram; evidence of 2 fore edge clasps closing from top to bottom; 3 fore edge tabs; on the front pastedown, a woodcut of the Crucifixion.|Figurative details, ff. 1-172v: Four historiated initials.|Script, ff. 1-172v: Rounded gothic book hand.|Layout, ff. 1-172v: Gatherings of 10 leaves, except for the 11th (of 8) and the last two (of 2, counting pastedown); 14 long lines ruled in ink.
note: Bibliography: Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1-172v: ff. i-iii verso, additions; ff. 1-79, Hours of the BVM; ff. 79v-80v, added prayers; ff. 81-105v, Penitential psalms & litany; ff. 106-108v, rhyming prayer in Italian; ff. 109-165, Office of the Dead; ff. 166-169v, Office of the Cross; ff. 170-172v, added.
acknowledgements: This description provided by D. J. Dutschke and C. W. Dutschke.

title_as_recorded: Chy fait mencion comment le Roy Henry d'Engleterre renvoya la Reyne Izabel jadis femme du Roy Richard d'Engleterre en France et de ceulx qui le rechevirent|History of France and England during the reigns of Henry IV, Henry V, Henry VI
former_owner_as_recorded: On front pastedown, pressmark, "a.37"; bookplate of Victor Albert George Child-Villiers (1845-1915), Earl of Jersey, Osterley Park; clipping from Sotheby's, lot 56; Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
former_owner_label: Victor Child Villiers, 7th Earl of Jersey;Adolph Sutro
physical_description: Binding: Early modern binding in panelled calf over paper boards.|Script, ff. 1-370: Cursive script.|Layout, ff. 1-370: 32-39 long lines, frame ruled in lead; contemporary foliationin roman numerals by scores.|Watermarks, ff. 1-370: Briquet 8651.
note: Bibliography: Eighth Report of the Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts, Report and Appendix, Pt. 1(London 1881), p. 100, n. 21. Not in De Ricci.|ff. 1-370; f. 370v blank: Many erasures and corrections as if a draft copy.|Explicit, ff. 1-370; f. 370v blank: Pour l'an mil iiii cent et viii aprez la mort du bon Roy Richard . . .

former_owner_as_recorded: Mr. James Orchard Halliwell-Phillips; Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco; bought at Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge auction, 1-4 July 1889.

Manuscripta9 (1965): 89-103 (p. 100).|1 leaf: Document clearly dated 1425; Dennis apparently assumes the calculus florentinus with the year beginning March 25.|Explicit, 1 leaf: Sale of a 26-year-old Russian slave named Maria by ser Luigi Loredano, son of the late Giovanni, to ser Gabriele Barbarigo, son of the late Antonio.|Docket: Sale of a 26-year-old Russian slave named Maria by ser Luigi Loredano, son of the late Giovanni, to ser Gabriele Barbarigo, son of the late Antonio.

Bibliography: Dennis, George T. "An Inventory of Italian Notarial Documents in the Sutro Library, San Francisco." Manuscripta9 (1965): 89-103 (p. 100).|Explicit, 1 leaf: Property agreement.|Docket: Property agreement.

title_as_recorded: Rhetorica ad Herennium|Summa de casibus conscientiae
standard_title: Rhetorica ad Herennium|Summa de casibus conscientiae
author_as_recorded: Pseudo Cicero|Bartholomaeus de S. Concordio (Bartholomaeus Pisanus)
former_owner_as_recorded: In an envelope with the manuscript, the remains of the bookplate of George John Warren Vernon (1803-1866), fifth Baron Veron; CSL accession number 22953.
physical_description: Binding: Quarter bound calf, nineteenth century.|Other decoration, ff. i-iv (front and back flyleaves): 2- and 3-line initials in gold with white-patterned pink and green infilling on square white-patterned blue grounds; 1-line initials within text washed with pale yellow.|Script, ff. i-iv (front and back flyleaves): Humanistic.|Layout, ff. i-iv (front and back flyleaves): 24 long lines; ruled.|Other decoration, ff. 1r-191v: 2- and 3-line initials in red, sometimes decorated in void; paraph marks in red.|Number of scribes, ff. 1r-191v: Several.|Script, ff. 1r-191v: Gothic and humanistic cursive.|Layout, ff. 1r-191v: 2 columns of 36 lines; ruled in ink.
note: ff. 1r-191v: The date on the last leaf, 1338, is that of the composition of the text, not of this copy.|ff. i-iv (front and back flyleaves): Continuous sequence of text from book 4 if read in the following order: f. iii r-v, ff. i r-ii v, f. iv r-v.|ff. 1r-191v: On f. 191v, column b, the resume' known as the Breviarum decretorumoften attributed to Johannes de Deo (see, for example, Jordan and Wool, Inventory of Western Manuscripts in the Biblioteca Ambrosianaregarding A 147 sup).
acknowledgements: ff. 1r-191v: Dr. Thomas Izbicki kindly identified the text on f. 191v.

title_as_recorded: Book of Hours, use of Rome
former_owner_as_recorded: Philip Jacob Grangier (1785); CSL assession number 18294.
physical_description: Binding: Brown calf, blind stamped.|Figurative details, ff. 1r-85v: 4 full page miniatures; 6 small miniatures; 7 historiated initials.|Other decoration, ff. 1r-85v: Large white-patterned initials in pink or blue on square gold grounds; 2-line initials in gold on alternating grounds of pink and blue; 1-line initials in alternating blue and gold with red or blue pen flourishing respectively.|Number of scribes, ff. 1r-85v: 1.|Script, ff. 1r-85v: Gothic.|Layout, ff. 1r-85v: 20 long lines ruled in pale red ink.
note: Manuscript note: Grangier bookplate inside front cover; donation note of Antonio Faurio (?) inside back cover.|ff. 1r-84r (ff. 84v-85v blank): Contains the Hours of the Virgin and the Penitential Psalms.
